Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Antarctic ELF/VLF Observations of Q-bursts, Radio Atmospherics, and Energetic Particle Precipitation
Award.AbstractNarration: The overarching goal of this award is to quantitatively investigate lightning and energetic particle precipitation from the Earth?s radiation belts using the extremely and very low frequency (ELF/VLF, ~5 Hz?32 kHz) observations on the Antarctic continent. A coordinated effort will fully characterize individual lightning return strokes occurring in the Northern hemisphere while simultaneously observing the associated ELF/VLF radio atmospheric (sferic) in the Antarctic (and other global locations). A special effort will focus on a class of large-amplitude ELF sferics known as Q-bursts in order to quantify global ionospheric conditions and the characteristics of the causative lightning flash. Narrowband VLF observations of lightning-induced electron precipitation (LEP) will be simultaneously conducted in the Northern and Southern hemispheres in order to validate a new LEP model that accounts for the lightning current waveform and return stroke speed. Furthermore, this program critically evaluates whether rocket-triggered lightning may be detected in the Antarctic, allowing for controlled broadband ELF/VLF propagation studies, and whether it may produce LEP in the conjugate hemisphere. The broader impacts of this award are in identifying direct effects of space weather events for the studies by atmospheric and space electricity research communities. The project introduces a new platform from which to conduct controlled lightning-related ELF/VLF experiments using rocket-triggered lightning in Florida, it provides real-time access to experimental observations via the Internet, and it exposes the program to youths through the operation of VLF receivers at high schools in the United States. The dissemination of program results also takes the form of refereed journal publications and conference presentations. The project will train graduate students with the development and operation of the deployed instruments, as well as with space weather science investigations. Use of these data to validate space weather models can provide benefit to society as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program had the following goals:

1)   To perform rocket-triggered lightning experiments in Florida to investigate the way lightning excites radio waves that propagate to great distances around the globe (including Antarctica).

2)   To perform experimental observations of lighting-induced electron precipitation event simultaneously in the northern and southern hemispheres.

3)   To investigate the source of a particular kind of lighting-associated burst called the Q-burst.

4)   To support ongoing ELF/VLF observations at Arrival Heights, Antarctica, to support ongoing VLF observations at Palmer Station, Antarctica and at South Pole Station, Antarctica, and to install a new ELF receiver at Palmer Station, Antarctica.

 

This program produced the following results:

1) We successfully triggered lightning on a number of occasions in North America and detected the ELF/VLF radiation in Antarctica.  The summer of 2016 was particularly good for detecting rocket-triggered lightning in Antarctica.  These observations are being used to show that the properties of the lightning channel can change significantly between return strokes, affecting the magnitude of the radio wave launched around the world.

2) We successfully detected a large number of conjugate LEP events.  We detected over 50 high quality observations of LEP events in the northern and southern hemispheres simultaneously.  We performed a statistical analysis of these events to determine the distribution of event timing and other properties.

3) We determined that many reported observations of Q-bursts since the 1990's are most likely observations of N-bursts – none of the observations have corresponding VLF observations to show a lack of signal in the VLF band.  We successfully identified a large number of strong ELF transients that indeed lack a corresponding VLF component, and these true Q-bursts are observed as such all over the globe.  We are investigating how these bursts affect the excitation of the global Schumann Resonance Band.

4) This program saved the VLF receiver at Palmer Station from the calving glacier.  We deployed a new ELF receiver to Palmer Station.  We performed detailed ELF/VLF noise surveys near McMurdo, and determined that Black Island is the best location for an additional ELF/VLF receiver.  We additionally performed detailed noise surveys at South Pole.  Each year, we calibrated the systems and kept the systems operating at peak performance.
